meta.name: Rhiley's Ultimate Design Styles & Color Theory Dataset
meta.description: Complete dataset of design aesthetics, color theory rules, palettes, combos, gradients, and UI mood boards for every type of project.
meta.author: Rhiley — Senior Frontend AI

colorProperties.hue: The pure color itself — position on the color wheel
colorProperties.saturation: Intensity or purity of the color (0% = grey, 100% = pure color)
colorProperties.lightness: How light or dark the color is (0% = black, 100% = white)
colorProperties.value: Brightness of the color (used in HSV model)
colorProperties.chroma: Colorfulness relative to white — similar to saturation but perceptual
colorProperties.temperature: Warm (reds, oranges, yellows) vs Cool (blues, greens, purples)

monochromatic.definition: Single hue with varying lightness and saturation
monochromatic.bestFor: Luxury brands, minimalism, editorial, premium SaaS

analogous.definition: 3-5 colors adjacent on the color wheel
analogous.bestFor: Nature brands, wellness, food, lifestyle, photography portfolios

example.name: Ocean Analogous
example.note: Blues and greens — ocean, nature, fresh

complementary.definition: Two colors directly opposite on the color wheel
complementary.bestFor: Sports brands, gaming, e-commerce CTAs, attention-grabbing UI

example.name: Purple & Yellow
example.note: Max contrast — use 60/30/10 to avoid visual chaos

splitComplementary.definition: Base color + two colors adjacent to its complement
splitComplementary.feel: High contrast but softer than pure complementary
splitComplementary.bestFor: Creative agencies, portfolios, bold but refined UI

triadic.definition: Three colors equally spaced on the color wheel (120° apart)
triadic.bestFor: Children's brands, playful apps, creative studios, bold editorial

example.name: Classic Triadic
example.note: Red, Green, Blue — always vibrant and rich

tetradic.definition: Four colors forming a rectangle on the color wheel
tetradic.feel: Complex, rich, varied — hard to balance

square.bestFor: Brand systems, design systems, complex UI

sixtyThirtyTen.description: The most reliable color balance rule for UI design

warm.bestFor: Food, restaurants, fitness, sales, urgency CTAs

minimalism.name: Minimalism
principles: Strong typographic hierarchy does the heavy lifting

typography.letter_spacing: tight to normal for body, wide for labels

colorPalettes.name: Paper White
colorPalettes.note: Pure minimal — nothing distracts

colorPalettes.name: Warm Sand
colorPalettes.note: Warm neutral with terracotta accent

colorPalettes.name: Ash Dark
colorPalettes.note: Dark minimalism — bold and stark

colorPalettes.name: Stone Light
colorPalettes.note: Earthy, gallery-like neutrals

brutalism.name: Brutalism / Neo-Brutalism
brutalism.vibe: Raw, bold, unapologetic, high contrast, intentionally rough
principles: Offset box shadows (4-8px solid, no blur)
Primary colors used flat and punchy
No rounded corners or very slight rounding
Heavy bold typography — condensed or display
Background often off-white or primary color

typography.display: Bebas Neue, Big Shoulders Display, Archivo Black

colorPalettes.name: Neo-Brutal Yellow
colorPalettes.note: Classic neo-brutal — yellow + black, hard shadows

colorPalettes.name: Neo-Brutal Pink
colorPalettes.note: Viral neo-brutal — hot pink + black

colorPalettes.name: Neo-Brutal Lime
colorPalettes.note: Electric lime — striking and modern

colorPalettes.name: Neo-Brutal Orange
colorPalettes.note: Aggressive orange — high energy

colorPalettes.name: Dark Brutal
colorPalettes.note: Dark brutal — reversed shadows with white borders

glassmorphism.name: Glassmorphism
glassmorphism.vibe: Frosted, translucent, layered depth, dreamy, premium
principles: Always needs a gradient or image background behind
Soft glow shadows, never hard shadows
Light content on dark blurred backgrounds works best

css.standard: background: rgba(255,255,255,0.08); backdrop-filter: blur(20px); border: 1px solid rgba(255,255,255,0.12);
css.heavy: background: rgba(255,255,255,0.12); backdrop-filter: blur(40px) saturate(180%); border: 1px solid rgba(255,255,255,0.2);
css.dark: background: rgba(0,0,0,0.25); backdrop-filter: blur(20px); border: 1px solid rgba(255,255,255,0.08);

principles: Muted, desaturated palette — no pure bright colors
Warm yellows, burnt oranges, mustards, sage greens
Serif or slab serif display fonts
Circular badges, ribbons, stamps as UI elements
No clean borders — rough or hand-drawn feel

dark_mode.name: Dark Mode / Dark UI
dark_mode.vibe: Modern, easy on eyes, premium, techy, sophisticated
principles: Never use pure black (#000) — use dark grays #0a-#1a range
Layered surfaces — each layer slightly lighter
Reduce saturation for secondary colors in dark mode
Bright accent pops on dark background
Text at 3 levels: primary, secondary (60% opacity), muted (40%)

gradientMesh.name: Gradient Mesh / Aurora
gradientMesh.vibe: Modern, vibrant, dynamic, dreamy, premium digital
principles: Soft blurred colored blobs in corners/background
High saturation colors but blurred into softness
Usually on dark or light base
Text must be readable — contrast check essential
Popular in modern SaaS landing pages

colorPalettes.note: Stripe-inspired mesh — purple cyan pink blobs

editorial.name: Editorial / Magazine
principles: Typography IS the design — font choices are everything
Strong grid — columns, gutters, baseline grid
Black and white with single spot color
Mix of serif and sans-serif in one layout
Rule lines, dividers, and grid guides as design elements

typography.display: Playfair Display, Bodoni Moda, DM Serif Display
typography.caption: Barlow, DM Sans, Public Sans

neumorphism.name: Neumorphism / Soft UI
principles: Background, shadow, and element are near same color
Creates illusion of elements pushed out or in
Works ONLY on light or medium surfaces, not dark
Never use pure white or black as base
Use for interactive elements: buttons, toggles, sliders

colorPalettes.name: Neumorphic Grey
colorPalettes.note: Classic neumorphism — grey base, blue accent

colorPalettes.name: Neumorphic Warm
colorPalettes.note: Warm neumorphism — cream with orange accent

conic.name: Color Wheel

monochromaticSets.name: Violet Scale
monochromaticSets.usage: Use lightest for bg, mid for accents, darkest for text on light

usageGuide.howToPickDesignStyle: Match the brand's personality first. Then match to industry norms. Then break them intentionally for differentiation.
colorPickingProcess: 1. Identify the vibe and emotion the design should evoke
2. Choose warm (energy/appetite) vs cool (trust/calm) vs neutral (luxury/minimal)
3. Pick a harmony type (complementary for contrast, analogous for harmony, monochromatic for sophistication)
4. Apply 60-30-10 rule to assign color weights
5. Check WCAG contrast ratios — minimum 4.5:1 for body text
6. Test in both light and dark mode
7. Check how it looks for color blind users (deuteranopia, protanopia)
gradientUsageRules: Use linear gradients for backgrounds, borders, text effects
Use radial gradients for glow effects and spotlight effects
Use conic gradients for color wheels, pie charts, decorative elements
Gradient text: always test contrast carefully — often hard to read
Max 3 colors in a gradient for readability
Angle matters: 135deg is most natural, 0deg/90deg feel rigid
usageGuide.greatdeskNote: Greatdesk is Rhiley's signature custom font. Load it from /public/fonts/ and it pairs beautifully with any sans or serif in this dataset.
